title: Variance and Standard Deviation of Discrete Random Variables
contentHtml:
The variance and standard deviation are fundamental measures of uncertainty in probability theory.

For a discrete random variable X with values x1, ..., xn and corresponding probabilities p1, ..., pn, the variance is defined as:

\(\sigma^2 = \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - E[X])^2 p_i\)

The standard deviation is simply the square root of the variance.

subject: probability
title: Variance and Standard Deviation of Discrete Random Variables
contentHtml:
The variance and standard deviation are fundamental measures of spread in probability theory.

They help us understand how a discrete random variable is distributed around its mean.

theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the standard deviation is equivalent to the square root of the variance.

intuition: The variance measures how spread out a distribution is, while the standard deviation is the square root of this measure. This helps us understand the magnitude of the spread.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, understanding the variance and standard deviation of features is crucial for model selection and performance evaluation.
